Mike

It does to some extent, because the underlying object would have to have
some amount of "correctness" to successfully pull off the interaction. But
what if a potential future interaction blows up because of a bug that is not
exposed by the first test?  At this point I am back to being less confident
that my code is correct, and I have to search for the posibility that there
is a bug in the interaction or a bug in the underlying objects that compose
the interaction.  At this point my scope of search is expanded costing me
more time than if the bug was exposed by a unit test.

Think of testing a 4 wheel drive.  I could test the a component (axle) in
unit fashion. "This axle will survive 20,000 ftlbs of torque"(I'm not a
mechanical engineer) This would give me level of confidence that the axle
would perform when put into the rest of the vehicle.  The other option is to
skip all the unit tests and just put the truck together and take it into the
field and hammer it to see what breaks.  As the Test driver I would be more
confident in the truck that had the part unit tested.

Hope this helps

Michael

-----Original Message-----
From: news [mailto:news@...]On Behalf Of Mike Bresnahan
Sent: Friday, June 20, 2003 4:33 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Re: Unit Testing vs Integration Testing


> Unit testing gives you confidence in your objects. Integration
> testing gives you confidence in the interaction between your objects.

Doesn't integration testing give you both confidence in the interaction
between your objects and confidence in your objects?

Mike Bresnahan
